abstract_summ: CONCLUSION A fourth of COVID-19 patients had elevated liver enzymes and associated with disease severity.CONCLUSION: We assessed the prevalence of comorbidities in the COVID-19 patients and found that underlying disease, including hypertension, respiratory system disease and cardiovascular disease, may be risk factors for severe patients compared with non-severe patients.The most prevalent comorbidities were hypertension (21.1%, 95% CI: 13.0–27.2%) and diabetes (9.7%, 95% CI: 7.2–12.2%), followed by cardiovascular disease (8.4%, 95% CI: 3.8–13.8%) and respiratory system disease (1.5%, 95% CI: 0.9–2.1%).Conclusions: The incidence of liver injury seems to be higher in patients with severe COVID-19 infection.Current meta-analysis of retrospective studies was done to summarize available findings on the association between liver injury and severity of COVID-19 infection.

title_abstract_phrases: Intensive monitoring for liver injury may be needed in cases with severe COVID-19.Risk factors for mortality in patients with Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) infection: a systematic review and meta-analysis of observational studies.CONCLUSION: We assessed the prevalence of comorbidities in the COVID-19 patients and found that underlying disease, including hypertension, respiratory system disease and cardiovascular disease, may be risk factors for severe patients compared with non-severe patients.CONCLUSION A fourth of COVID-19 patients had elevated liver enzymes and associated with disease severity.It is still need additional studies to support the conclusions and to explore the AKI mechanism during COVID-19 infection.STUDY SELECTION: Studies were included in our meta-analysis if it was published in peer-reviewed journals and recorded patient characteristics of severe versus nonsevere or survivor versus nonsurvivor in coronavirus disease 2019 infection.
